***READ THE GUIDE***

THE GUIDE: http://gunpla.buyfags.moe/

***READ THE GUIDE***

For those new to gunpla/plamo or even just new to this thread; please read the guide. Please read it before asking questions, as there is a chance it has already been answered there.

For those unfamiliar, "plamo" is a shortened form of "plastic model". If it's made of plastic, someone can probably help you here!
If you're new, you're gonna fuck up. Don't worry! If you're experienced, don't make the new people worry!

And remember to report any shitposting and spam to keep the thread clean and civil.

>Why won't anyone answer my question?
Try being specific, especially about your materials and process. Post images whenever possible; even if the kit/part looks bad, you are more likely to get help posting images.

>Why are my pictures sideways?
4chan strips EXIF data from images when they're uploaded to the site from your phone, including the orientation display tag. To fix this, save your images separately, or use an app that will rotate and save the images for you.
One commonly used app that works well on Android:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.simplemobilephotoresizer

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21280856
>kampfer in MA format
>what the fuck why

Kampfer is 18.2m so it is in the MS Format. The "Heavy Assaults" I was referring to were things like Queen Mansa, the Psychos, The O and Destroy. The rule of thumb is that if a suit is 20m or larger it is HA/MA.

>this is why most hobbyist circles run cost systems rather than classification systems

Both are important. Pure point costs ended up creating a "no weapons just size and defenses" meta where disarmed "HAs" could literally crush all non-HA opposition with punches, kicks and other physical attacks (seeing a Messala take out a Nemo by sitting on it is funny only the first few times after a while it just gets sad) while to costing the same as a fully armed standard MS. Moving the HAs to the MA format allowed smaller and more weapon reliant builds to actually function.

The popularity of the unarmed HA meta is likely why the first AU was the melee focused G Gundam.

>>21280699
>and the colony laser wiped out about 1/3rd of their forces
Half their attacking forces, equal to 1/3 of the EFSF navy. Not to mention they were assaulting a fortified position with base defenses on top of that.

>nd that's just the Ground Gundams, there were probably dozens more Ground GMs and other suits too.
That's Ground GMs and Gundams combined. There were only 20 Ground Gundams produced (HGUC manual) and around 50 Ground GMs (Master Archive RGM-79), including modified units like the BD-0 and BD-1. Those were the majority of the units produced operating in Eurasia before GMs started rolling out of Jaburo. Meanwhile Zakus were rolled out in the thousands and the INITIAL Earth Drop operation led by Garma had 5 MS divisions drop across earth, totaling to around 910 MS by Mark Simmons's calculations + 90 from M'Quave's forces, for around 1000 Zaku types on Earth at the start of the Earth invasion. vs what, 70 Ground GMs and Gundams combined, with single digit MP Guntanks.
https://www.mechatalk.net/viewtopic.php?t=15486
>As we know, Zeon has five terrestrial mobile divisions. If they all have this same standard fighting strength - unlikely in practice, but possible on paper - then the entire Earth Attack Force would start out with 910 mobile suits....

>...plus M'quve's mining detachment, which was deployed separately and answers to a separate chain of command. If that's organized as a single battalion, that would be another 90 mobile suits, bringing the starting total to exactly 1000 machines.

Plus the MG manuals back up Zeon's number superiority. There were only 330 RGM-79 types known to be produced from the first few batches. It's not clear how many if any of the later batches were introduced into the OYW but we do know the last batch was downsized to being made mostly at California Base.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21279808

It did, just not much because it's not a big hole and given just how big a colony cylinder is (8km by 36km) the atmosphere would take literally days or even weeks to completely drain, depending on the size of the hole. It'd be hours before anyone noticed a real drop in pressure. Maybe more. Cylinders have auto protection for smaller holes too, and you see some gum release to cover the hole blown in a colony in the first episode of Zeta.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>Amuro newtype NTRs Lalah away from Char or something
What the fuck is going on in these episodes.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21280868

I'd have thought it pretty clearly explained. Char is using Lalah for her powers because he knows he wants to defeat the Gundam for the sake of his own pride, but recognizes the Gundam and it's pilot have become too strong a combination and he can't do it on his own, while Lalah is happy to help Char despite recognizing that he's using her because he saved her life in some unspecified way in the past and she is willing to lay down her life to repay that. Char is attracted to her despite the fact he's just using her for her power, and so they start a relationship, because again, Lalah feels indebted to him.

When Char and Lalah visit the Texas colony, Lalah feels a presence touching her mind while riding in a wagon with Char and Dr. Flanagan, which she assumes it's Char, because she doesn't know anyone else around and nothing like that has ever happened to her before, but Char is just confused as to what she's saying and she eventually realizes it's the Gundam pilot. They have a few more moments as they battle over a couple of episodes, with Lalah eventually starting to question whether she was wrong to attach herself to Char so strongly and lamenting the tragedy that she met Amuro after Char because she actually feels something beyond a debt to him.

The novel version goes into more detail from Char's side, since novel Char eventually realizes after Lalah's death that he didn't actually love her but just felt a protective instinct for her and was mistaking that for love, before moving on to form a much healthier relationship with one of Kycilia's secretaries, Margaret Ring Blair. Amuro continues to lament her death though, even while he and Sayla hook up, and his final scene in the novel is his spirit fading alongside Lalahs once he dies. The animation doesn't take the exact same route obviously, but the general vibe of Char mostly having a savior complex but Amuro actually loving her as being true.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21280206
>I dont really understand how bigger, non-articulated claws are an "upgrade
Simplification; the old hands couldn't use any weapons besides the specially shaped beam sabers and presumably the entire forearm was more complex since you had to wrap the actuators around a mega particle cannon. By separating them you no longer have to compromise on the strength of the grip, you can use bigger actuators for the same space so it's better in melee, and reduce complexity of the gun, since it doesn't have to take sharing space with the other arm components in consideration.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21278447

It's a common take, even if you find it weird, because Gato not only never actually considers or questions what he's doing in any fashion despite setting out to restart an intensenly bloody war that had finished several years previously in any fashion, but both he and Gato have a warped view of the actual ideology they claim to be following that doesn't actually match what we see previously at all and just comes off as them huffing some serious farts to arrive at that conclusion. Nowhere in the original show, movies, novels etc. does Gihren ever talk about caring for the future of Spacenoids as a whole, but they are convinced that he's some kind of revolutionary God and are so repulsed by the rest of his family that they literally abandon ship the second they even think he might be dead. They never confirm it with anyone; they just assume they're right given circumstantial evidence, and leave.

Plus, he talks a big game about how Kou needs to stand back and look at the big picture if he wants to be more than a common grunt and has to have ideals; but he's full of shit, since even with all his talk of idealism, his actions were still never more than those of a pawn in someone else's plan that ended up empowering the very things he was so obsessed with fighting against.

Gato is motivated, passionate and zealous; but none of that makes him not brainwashed, because those are not mutually exclusive and, often seen as hallmarks of being brainwashed in the first place.

They picked Gihren because he was the leader (i.e. the actual, real leader and not a figurehead like Degwin), and literally nothing else about his character mattered because they ignored or re-wrote everything else to suit their own purposes anyway. According to Gato and Delaz, Gihren was fighting a revolutionary war for the freedom of all Spacenoids; which is complete and utter horseshit. The revolution bit at least matches some rhetoric that is in 0079, though I'm not sure anyone in the show itself calls the war a revolution and I only remember the narrator calling it that, but neither Gihren nor any of the other Zabis gave a single solitary fuck about any of the other Sides beyond Side 3. Which is why they were happy to attack 4 of them as their opening to the war, slaughtering literally billions of people.

Only, because no-one else actually gives any other view on the matter, it comes off as being a completely straight and unironic view by Gato and Delaz that represents not just what they think, but what the show in general thinks of Gihren, despite bearing no similarity to anything that came before it. So Gihren could have been eating livd babies washed down with the blood of conscripts for brunch on the daily, and keeping a 6 year named Gato Jr. as a sex slave during the events of 0079 and it wouldn't have made a blind bit of difference to the writing of 0083, because 0083 would just ignore it anyway.

Interviewer: As a fan, I'm sure there is a part of you that is looking forward to the visualization of "Hakaioh" by Yonetani, how do you feel about that?
Yonetani: When I was young, I thought I could do it, so I proposed the project, but as I got older, the staff and cast also got older, and some of the people involved in the project have passed away. I wanted to make the visualization as soon as possible, but I thought it would be difficult at this time. I myself am not as strong as I was back then. However, I'm not the type of person who can just be the general director and leave it to someone else, so it's difficult to make an anime. Hakaioh is also a heavy work, and if I were to direct every detail myself, I would run out of time. If technological innovation progresses, and if by some miracle the truly talented staff can come together and say, "Let's do it! I might be able to make it happen. At the time of the first "GaoGaiGar", the number of anime productions was decreasing, and staff from other studios were often free. When I asked for help, everyone came and helped me. I was really touched by that. It was like a story in an anime, where an elite group of people came to help us in a pinch. I was so moved that I got goosebumps. I was so moved that I got goosebumps. In that sense, I think my life as a director was lucky. There is a serious shortage of human resources these days, so if something miraculous like that happens in the future, I feel that I might be able to make another work.

>>21276749
Advance of Zeta starts in UC 0084. Meanwhile, Sentinel takes place in UC 0088. The reason some of the designs look similar is because they are roughly the same tech level. There is most definitely some overlap in unit role. Keep in mind that Zeta Gundam takes place in 0087 and ZZ takes place in 0088, and the big picture becomes more clear - units like the Byarlant and Messala are just refined and stylized designs developed from the Titans Test program. I particularly enjoy seeing these same designs carried forward in shows like Unicorn and Hathaway. I hated most of Narrative, but I loved Banagher’s Silver Bullet Suppressor, which is a descendant of the Mk. V and Döven Wulf.

threads.com:
What is the best way to download (or buy) Force Five material these days?
Specifically looking for their adaptation of Danguard Ace, because I can't find it anywhere online except for a few bootleg DVD stores and a couple of dead Youtube links.
Internet Archive hosts nearly everything else from the anthology (along with a truckload of other old dubs), but the only entries pertaining to their version of Danguard are recordings of the theme song and a scanned VHS sleeve.
One of the comments in pic related kinda makes me wonder if the bootleg BD author found some episodes of the elusive Hawaiian or Filipino english dubs, though it’s more likely that they just pinched lines from the 2013 re-dub films, had to source from tapes of highly varying quality/condition, or even re-recorded lines himself. Considering that Asuka The Disc Dog has a reputation for selling disks with missing or broken audio tracks such things wouldn’t be too surprising.

As for Danguard itself it’s a pretty great show from what I’ve seen through the aforementioned newer dub (fun MOTW action and adventures, good melodrama, crisp animation) and I’d like to have some kind of an alternative to the ARR subs, in case they’re just as bad as some of the group’s other output.

I have no nostalgic attachment to any of these shows or dubs, I just happen to like a few 70s anime and also find the Yank dubs kinda interesting in terms of how well their source materials survived the edits and low-rent voice acting.

While I’m at it, what are your favorite ”pre-Akira” dubs of /m/-related media, be it for genuine quality/charm or just something to snicker at?
M&M Communication’s Mazinger Z is a pretty strong and faithful effort, complete with Isao Sasaki’s translated songs, and as a fan of ”dad jokes” I find ZIV’s second volume of Captain Harlock pretty funny at times. If I can’t laugh /with/ the jokes I'll at least have a hearty chuckle at the fact that it was an officially licensed mass-market tape.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
it's one of the worst turret designs I have ever seen. It's attached to the hull with a mere metal plate with nothing to support it structurally wise. And the main gun is positioned in such a way that it would have been outright impossible to load any shells into it. The machine guns, despite their mountings are effectively coaxial MGs because the way the ammo belts are loaded into them limits the traverse. And last but not least it possesses no optics, and the only ones visible are mounted on the hull, effectively limiting the Vanagandr's environmental awareness to directly in front of it.

Overall, neither do I understand why the Feds kept it as their main AFV, it's such an incompetent design it would have worked better as a Republican vehicle. I have a hard time believing that the same nation that designed the Lowe designed this. The Vanagandr IMO should have just been a manned version of the Lowe, with a different paintjob and more blocky design, not this demonic mechanical spider from hell.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>21278825

You say that like it's just AU. A lot of UC content doesn't even really benefit from being part of Gundam. The obvious ones are F91 and Victory, but even ZZ had much that required it be a Gundam show, and honestly, I'm not even sure Zeta needed to be one personally. Yes, Char as Quattro benefits from the audience knowing his previous act as an antagonist, but pretty much every other returning element is fairly superficial. I mostly just dislike how the setting does not feel remotely like it follows on less than a decade from an apocalyptic war that killed more than of humanity and destroyed hundreds of city-state/colony cylinders though, because the Sides never seem like they're actually affected by it at all. The Earth does, if only because Blex talks about environmental concerns, but watching Zeta you'd never realize that hundreds of colony cylinders and billions of people inhabiting them had been killed a little more than a handful of years previously.

I don't really mind it personally, since the name "Gundam" means very little beyond some persistent themes and hasn't since at least the early 90s, but if it's a problem then it's a problem with UC as well as AUs.

threads.com:
***READ THE GUIDE***

THE GUIDE: http://gunpla.buyfags.moe/

***READ THE GUIDE***

For those new to gunpla/plamo or even just new to this thread; please read the guide. Please read it before asking questions, as there is a chance it has already been answered there.

For those unfamiliar, "plamo" is a shortened form of "plastic model". If it's made of plastic, someone can probably help you here!
If you're new, you're gonna fuck up. Don't worry! If you're experienced, don't make the new people worry!

And remember to report any shitposting and spam to keep the thread clean and civil.

>Why won't anyone answer my question?
Try being specific, especially about your materials and process. Post images whenever possible; even if the kit/part looks bad, you are more likely to get help posting images.

>Why are my pictures sideways?
4chan strips EXIF data from images when they're uploaded to the site from your phone, including the orientation display tag. To fix this, save your images separately, or use an app that will rotate and save the images for you.
One commonly used app that works well on Android:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.simplemobilephotoresizer
